results.title: Bacteria and Health
results.brief_description: Diagrams and experiments show that by taking simple precautions such as disinfecting and dressing wounds, washing hands in soapy water and being aware of the presence of bacteria, we can remain healthy. It also discusses the ways in which our bodies cope with bacteria, and whether they are useful or harmful to the body.

results.title: Bacteria
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains external and internal structures, manner of feeding, reproductive processes, classifications, and the ecological importance of bacteria. Also shows cell division and conjugation. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Backward civilisation
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Yale University
results.brief_description: A survey of the life among the Berber people of North Africa including aspects of their daily life such as their handcrafts, agricultural methods, customs and superstitions.

results.title: Backstage at the Kirov
results.brief_description: The splendour of ballet is for so many a world of dreams and miracles. This movie invites us to be part of the passion and dedication blended with the grinding agony of training and rehearsal at the backstage of the famous Kirov Theatre in Leningrad.

results.title: Background for reading: stories of Holland
results.brief_description: Views of Holland are used to provide a background to Dutch literature: views of windmills; canals; dairy farms and farm houses; fishing boats on the Zuyder Zee; old-fashioned costumes worn by the people; the dikes; tulip growing; views of the town of Leiden; Rembrandt’s studio and the old Church of St Peter’s.

results.title: Background for literature: The Lady of the lake
results.brief_description: Scottish scenes are used to illustrate excerpts from Sir Walter Scott’s poem “Lady of the lake”. The film, which includes a brief outline of the author’s life, is intended to demonstrate the concept that literature has its roots in actual places and people.

results.title: Back room of the sky
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of work carried out at the Ministry of Aviation Research Centre at Boscombe Down. Aiming always for increased safety and efficiency, all sections of a new aircraft must be rigorously tested and teams of pilots, scientists and engineers seek out any flaws which must be corrected before a machine becomes operational. The men who will fly the aircraft are also seen undergoing tests at Boscombe Down. Narrated by Raymond Baxter.

group_siblings.title: Look at life: Bronze silver and gold

results.title: Back in circulation
results.brief_description: This film looks at a group of amputee soldiers, shortly after the Second World War. It looks at their rehabilitation, beginning with a visit to the “Limbless Soldiers Association, N.S.W.Aquatic Club” where soldiers come together for a water carnival. The film goes on to the Lady Gowrie Hospital and the Rehabilitation Artificial Limb Factory where the workers are amputees. No other credits available.

results.title: Baby crazy
results.brief_description: Being a parent is one of humanity’s most demanding and rewarding experiences - a mixture of infatuation, mad passion, fear, fun, guilt and enduring love. This amusing documentary looks at four young couples who share their intimate experiences of parenting by providing privileged access to rare moments on home video recordings and interviews. It’s a fascinating story of how a family grows and changes. “Baby Crazy” is narrated by well known actress Noni Hazelhurst, and is almost required viewing for soon to be parents, baby watchers, and baby lovers. It shows all the sensual, tender, crazy and fun-filled aspects of babyhood along with the pain and not so fun-filled aspects of having a child. Inspired by the book “Baby Crazy” by Helen Townsend.
